et: borrowed from French {it}antonyme,{/it} probably back-formation (after {it}synonyme{/it} {et_link|synonym|synonym}) from {it}antonymie{/it} {ldquo}opposition of words with contrary senses,{rdquo} borrowed from Greek {it}antōnymía{/it} {ldquo}pronoun (i.e., a word substituting for another), interchange of names,{rdquo} from {it}ant-, anti-{/it} {ldquo}in opposition to, in place of{rdquo} + {it}-ōnymos{/it} {ldquo}having a name (of the kind specified){rdquo} + {it}-ia{/it} {et_link|-ia:1|-ia:1} {ma}{mat|anti-|}, {mat|homonymous|} {/ma}

French {it}antonyme{/it} appears in the title and text of {it}Dictionnaire des antonymes ou contremots{/it} (Paris & Berlin, 1842), an early dictionary of antonyms compiled from 17th-18th-century authors by the Alsatian philologist Paul Ackermann (1812-46), who may have coined the word. In English {it}antonym{/it} was promulgated, if not first used, by the British clergyman Charles John Smith (1819-72) in {it}Synonyms and Antonyms, Collected and Contrasted{/it} (London: Bell & Daldy, 1867), which went through several subsequent editions and reprints.
